field_edited_text.value:
"9





Planned Development

Baltimore City Landfill. The City has
purchased approximately 142 acres from
the W.R. Grace Co. to develop as a domes-
tic landfill. The site located north of
Hawkins Point Road and between Quaran-
tine and Chemical Roads should provide
the City with landfill capacity for 10 to 20
years.



Issues and Problems

Two projects in Anne Arundel County
outside the boundaries of Hawkins Point
promise to have an impact on the area’s
future. The first development project in
Anne Arundel County affecting the future
of Hawkins Point is the Brandon Shores
Power Generating Station being built by
the Baltimore Gas and Electric Co. The .
station will contain two coal fired units,
one scheduled to go into operation in
1984, the other in 1987. When both units
are running, they will burn 2.5-million tons
of coal per year. In addition, two oil-
powered generating units at the Wagner
Power Plant immediately adjacent to
Brandon Shores are being overhauled for
coal use. After the conversion is completed
by 1990, the Wagner Station will require 1.2
million tons of coal per year.

Coal barge passing Bethlehem Steel’s Sparrows Point plant

Plans call for coal to be brought to
both generating stations by barge. The
second project also involves the Baltimore
Gas and Electric Co. A subsidiary plans to
develop an industrial park on land owned
by B.G.&E.

Rail Issues: Pennington Avenue is the
only route into Hawkins Point and Marley
Neck from the north. The anticipated
increase in the number of trains to service
new industry could block access not only
for employees and trucks, but also for
emergency vehicles. Grade separation at
this point will be a high priority to the City,
but will be costly.

In addition, Glidden, Gypsum, Cosmin
and Kennecott could all be blocked by
train movement across grade crossings lead-
ing to their properties. Further, the CSX rail
line crosses Curtis Creek into Hawkins
Point via a swing bridge. When trains are
crossing the bridge, Coast Guard vessels
cannot move into the harbor from the
Coast Guard Station further south on Curtis
Creek. There has to be careful coordina-
tion between the trains and the Coast
Guard to prevent any delay in answering
emergency calls from vessels in the harbor.

Traffic Issues: The City is planning
improvements to Pennington Avenue.
Improvements to portions of Hawkins Point
Road have been completed and additional
upgrading is projected for the future.



50
